title: Liquidity trap
text:
A liquidity trap is a situation, described in <a href="Keynesian%20economics">Keynesian economics</a>, in which, "after the <a href="rate%20of%20interest">rate of interest</a> has fallen to a certain level, <a href="liquidity%20preference">liquidity preference</a> may become virtually absolute in the sense that almost everyone prefers holding <a href="cash">cash</a> rather than holding a debt (<a href="financial%20instrument">financial instrument</a>) which yields so low a rate of interest."
A liquidity trap is caused when people hoard cash because they <a href="Expectation%20%28epistemic%29">expect</a> an adverse event such as <a href="deflation">deflation</a>, insufficient <a href="aggregate%20demand">aggregate demand</a>, or <a href="war">war</a>. Among the characteristics of a liquidity trap are interest rates that are close to zero and changes in the <a href="money%20supply">money supply</a> that fail to translate into changes in the price level.
Origin and definition of the term.
<a href="John%20Maynard%20Keynes">John Maynard Keynes</a>, in his 1936 <a href="General%20Theory%20of%20Employment%2C%20Interest%20and%20Money">"General Theory"</a>, wrote the following: There is the possibility...that, after the rate of interest has fallen to a certain level, liquidity-preference may become virtually absolute in the sense that almost everyone prefers cash to holding a debt which yields so low a rate of interest. In this event the monetary authority would have lost effective control over the rate of interest. But whilst this limiting case might become practically important in future, I know of no example of it hitherto.
This concept of <a href="monetary%20policy">monetary policy</a>'s potential impotence was first suggested in the works of British economist <a href="John%20Hicks">John Hicks</a>, inventor of <a href="IS%E2%80%93LM%20model">IS–LM model</a>ing. In fact, <a href="Nobel%20Memorial%20Prize%20in%20Economic%20Sciences">Nobel laureate</a> <a href="Paul%20Krugman">Paul Krugman</a>, in his work on monetary policy, follows the original formulations of Hicks:A liquidity trap may be defined as a situation in which conventional monetary policies have become impotent, because nominal interest rates are at or near zero: injecting <a href="monetary%20base">monetary base</a> into the economy has no effect, because [monetary] base and <a href="Bond%20%28finance%29">bond</a>s are viewed by the <a href="private%20sector">private sector</a> as perfect substitutes. In a liquidity trap, people are indifferent between bonds and cash because the rates of interest both <a href="financial%20instruments">financial instruments</a> provide to their holder is practically equal: The interest on cash is zero and the interest on bonds is near-zero. Hence, the central bank cannot affect the interest rate any more (through augmenting the <a href="monetary%20base">monetary base</a>) and has lost control over it.
Elaboration.
In Keynes' description of a liquidity trap, people simply do not want to hold bonds and prefer other, non-liquid forms of money instead. Because of this preference, after converting bonds into cash, this causes an incidental but significant decrease to the bonds' prices and a subsequent increase to their yields. However, people prefer cash no matter how high these yields are or how high the central bank sets the bond's rates (yields).
<a href="Post-Keynesian%20economist">Post-Keynesian economist</a> <a href="Hyman%20Minsky">Hyman Minsky</a> posited that "after a debt <a href="deflation">deflation</a> that induces a deep <a href="Depression%20%28economics%29">depression</a>, an increase in the <a href="money%20supply">money supply</a> with a fixed head count of other <a href="financial%20asset">[financial] assets</a> may not lead to a rise in the price of other assets." This naturally causes interest rates on assets that are not considered "almost perfectly liquid" to rise. In which case, as Minsky had stated elsewhere,The view that the liquidity-preference function is a demand-for-money relation permits the introduction of the idea that in appropriate circumstances the demand for money may be infinitely <a href="Elasticity%20%28economics%29">elastic</a> with respect to variations in the interest rate… The liquidity trap presumably dominates in the immediate aftermath of a great depression or financial crisis.
Historical debate.
In the wake of the <a href="Keynesian%20revolution">Keynesian revolution</a> in the 1930s and 1940s, various <a href="Neoclassical%20economics">neoclassical economists</a> sought to minimize the effect of liquidity-trap conditions. <a href="Don%20Patinkin">Don Patinkin</a> and <a href="Lloyd%20Metzler">Lloyd Metzler</a> invoked the existence of the so-called "<a href="Pigou%20effect">Pigou effect</a>", in which the stock of real money balances is ostensibly an argument of the <a href="aggregate%20demand">aggregate demand</a> function for goods, so that the <a href="monetary%20base">money stock</a> would directly affect the "investment saving" curve in <a href="IS/LM%20model">IS/LM</a> analysis. <a href="Monetary%20policy">Monetary policy</a> would thus be able to stimulate the economy even when there is a liquidity trap.
<a href="Monetarist">Monetarist</a>s, most notably <a href="Milton%20Friedman">Milton Friedman</a>, <a href="Anna%20Schwartz">Anna Schwartz</a>, <a href="Karl%20Brunner%20%28economist%29">Karl Brunner</a>, <a href="Allan%20Meltzer">Allan Meltzer</a> and others, strongly condemned any notion of a "trap" that did not feature an environment of a zero, or near-zero, interest rate across the whole spectrum of interest rates, i.e. both short- and long-term debt of the government and the private sector. In their view, any interest rate different from zero along the yield curve is a sufficient condition to eliminate the possibility of the presence of a liquidity trap.
In recent times, when the Japanese economy <a href="Lost%20Decade%20%28Japan%29">fell</a> into a period of prolonged <a href="economic%20stagnation">stagnation</a>, despite near-zero interest rates, the concept of a liquidity trap returned to prominence. Keynes's formulation of a liquidity trap refers to the existence of a horizontal <a href="demand">demand</a>-curve for money at some positive level of interest rates; yet, the liquidity trap invoked in the 1990s referred merely to the presence of <a href="Zero%20interest-rate%20policy">zero or near-zero interest-rates</a> policies (ZIRP), the assertion being that interest rates could not fall below zero. Some economists, such as <a href="Nicholas%20Crafts">Nicholas Crafts</a>, have suggested a policy of <a href="inflation">inflation</a>-targeting (by a <a href="central%20bank">central bank</a> that is independent of the government) at times of prolonged, very low, nominal interest-rates, in order to avoid a liquidity trap or escape from it.
Some <a href="Austrian%20School">Austrian School</a> economists, such as those of the <a href="Ludwig%20von%20Mises%20Institute">Ludwig von Mises Institute</a>, reject Keynes' theory of liquidity preference altogether. They argue that lack of domestic investment during periods of low interest-rates is the result of previous <a href="malinvestment">malinvestment</a> and <a href="time%20preference">time preference</a>s rather than <a href="liquidity%20preference">liquidity preference</a>. <a href="Chicago%20school%20%28economics%29">Chicago school economists</a> remain critical of the notion of liquidity traps.
Keynesian economists, like Brad DeLong and <a href="Simon%20Wren-Lewis">Simon Wren-Lewis</a>,maintain that the economy continues to operate within the <a href="IS-LM%20model">IS-LM model</a>, albeit an "updated" one, and the rules have "simply changed."
Global financial crises of 2008 and 2020.
During the <a href="Global%20Financial%20Crisis">Global Financial Crisis</a>, in the period 2008–2010, as short-term interest rates for the various central banks in the United States and Europe moved close to zero, economists such as <a href="Paul%20Krugman">Paul Krugman</a> argued that much of the developed world, including the United States, Europe, and Japan, was in a liquidity trap. He noted that tripling of the <a href="monetary%20base">monetary base</a> in the US between 2008 and 2011 failed to produce any significant effect on domestic price indices or dollar-denominated commodity prices, a notion supported by others, such as <a href="Scott%20Sumner">Scott Sumner</a>.
<a href="U.S.%20Federal%20Reserve">U.S. Federal Reserve</a> economists assert that the liquidity trap can explain low inflation in periods of vastly increased central bank money supply. Based on experience $3.5 trillion of <a href="quantitative%20easing">quantitative easing</a> from 2009–2013, the hypothesis is that investors hoard and do not spend the increased money because the <a href="opportunity%20cost">opportunity cost</a> of holding cash (namely the interest forgone) is zero when the nominal interest rate is zero. This hoarding effect is purported to have reduced consequential inflation to half of what would be expected directly from the increase in the money supply, based on statistics from the expansive years. They further assert that the liquidity trap is possible only when the economy is in deep <a href="recession">recession</a>.
Modest inflation during the <a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> crisis in 2020, despite unprecedented monetary stimulus and expansion, was similarly ascribed to hoarding of cash. The M1 <a href="money%20supply">money supply</a> (currency and demand deposits and other checkable deposits which pay negligible interest) exploded from $4 trillion to $20 trillion during this period, consistent with the theorized hoarding of a liquidity trap.
Post-Keynesians respond that the confusion by "mainstream economists" between conditions of a liquidity trap, as defined by Keynes and in the Post-Keynesian framework, and conditions of near-zero or zero interest rates, is intentional and ideologically motivated in ostensibly attempting to support monetary over fiscal policies. They argue that, <a href="quantitative%20easing">quantitative easing</a> programs in the United States, and elsewhere, caused the prices of financial assets to rise across the board and <a href="interest%20rate">interest rate</a>s to fall; yet, a liquidity trap cannot exist, according to the Keynesian definition, unless the prices on imperfectly safe financial assets are falling and their interest rates are rising. The rise in the monetary base did not affect interest rates or commodity prices.
Taking the precedent of the Global Financial Crisis of 2008, critics of the mainstream definition of a liquidity trap point out that the central bank of the United States never, effectively, lost control of the interest rate. Whereas the United States did experience a liquidity trap in the period 2009/10, i.e. in "the immediate aftermath" of the crisis, the critics of the mainstream definition claim that, after that period, there is no more of any kind of a liquidity trap since government and private-sector bonds are "very much in demand". This goes against Keynes' point as Keynes stated that "almost everyone prefers cash to holding a debt." However, modern finance has the concept of <a href="cash%20and%20cash%20equivalents">cash and cash equivalents</a>; <a href="United%20States%20Treasury%20security">Treasuries</a> may in some cases be treated as cash equivalents and not "debt" for liquidity purposes.
